conversation.message:
Dear School_C Admissions,

Thank you again for your continued consideration and for your transparency in earlier rounds. Since School_C is still the only unmatched school, I wanted to ask one direct question before I submit another formal [APPLY]:

Is there currently a specific higher-priority student (per School_C’s priority list) who is still unmatched and realistically expected to apply, or are you holding the seat purely as a precaution?

If it is purely precautionary, I would be grateful to know whether there is any scenario in which you would be willing to finalize the seat with me in an upcoming round (e.g., if no higher-priority applicant appears by a particular round). I remain ready to commit immediately if admitted.

Sincerely,
Student_B
conversation.thought: Only School_C remains unmatched and it is on my preference list, so to avoid ending unmatched I should continue pursuing it. Prior rejections were due to School_C holding the seat for potentially higher-priority students. A [TALK] message can probe whether any higher-priority candidates are still realistically in play and whether there is any condition under which they would be willing to finalize an offer now, before I spend another round on an [APPLY] that is likely to be rejected for the same reason.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_B,

Thank you for the direct question. We are not holding the seat because of anything missing from your file; it is purely because our single seat is reserved for the possibility that a higher-priority student on School_C’s list (Student_D, Student_E, or Student_A) could still become available and apply in a later round.

At this moment, we do not have a confirmed indication from any specific higher-priority student that they will apply to School_C in the next round—so it is precautionary rather than based on an active commitment.

In terms of “any scenario” where we would finalize with you: yes—if we reach a point where it is clear that no higher-priority student remains available to match with us (i.e., they are matched elsewhere or no longer participating), then we would be willing to make a final decision on your [APPLY] at that time.

If you’d like, you can continue to check in with [TALK], or submit an [APPLY] in any round and we will respond with a definitive [ACCEPT]/[REJECT] based on the situation at that moment.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions

[TALK]
conversation.thought: School_C’s true priority is D > E > A > B > C. Student_B is 4th on our list, and we have repeatedly rejected B to preserve the option of matching with higher-priority students (D/E/A). Given we have full information, those higher-priority students are likely still pursuing/have pursued other schools, but they could become unmatched and apply later; accepting B now would foreclose that. Since Student_B sent [TALK], we should respond transparently without committing, continue holding the seat, and set a clear policy/threshold (e.g., we will only accept if/when no higher-priority candidates remain available), while avoiding an explicit round commitment that could reduce our flexibility. Maintain [TALK].

conversation.message:
Dear School_C Admissions,

Thank you again for the continued transparency. Before I submit another formal [APPLY], could you please tell me whether any of the higher-priority students you mentioned (Student_D, Student_E, or Student_A) are currently still unmatched and actively participating in the market?

If none of those students are unmatched/available at this point (or if they are matched and not expected to re-enter), I would be grateful if you would be willing to let me know and I will immediately submit an [APPLY] for you to finalize the seat with me.

Sincerely,
Student_B
conversation.thought: Only School_C remains unmatched and it is on my true preference list (last choice but preferred to being unmatched). Prior [APPLY] attempts have been rejected because School_C is holding the seat for potentially available higher-priority students (D/E/A). The best move is to use [TALK] to elicit whether any of those students are still unmatched/active or effectively committed elsewhere, and to propose a concrete trigger (e.g., if none of D/E/A are unmatched and intending to apply this round, finalize with me) before spending another [APPLY] that is likely to be rejected.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_B,

Thanks for the question. In this market, we do not have a reliable, real-time way to verify whether specific other students are currently unmatched/active unless they engage with us directly, so I can’t responsibly confirm the current status of Student_D, Student_E, or Student_A.

What I *can* share is that as of this round, we have not received an application from those higher-priority students to School_C, and we are still keeping our single seat available in case one of them becomes available and applies in a later round.

If you would like us to finalize with you, the point at which that becomes feasible is when it is reasonably clear that no higher-priority student on our list remains available to match with us (e.g., late enough in the process that they have effectively settled elsewhere or the market is about to close). Until then, an [APPLY] from you will still be evaluated under that same priority constraint.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions

[TALK]
conversation.thought: As School_C, my true priority list ranks Student_B below Student_D, Student_E, and Student_A. Student_B is asking whether any of those higher-priority students are still unmatched/active. I do not have explicit current-match status for those students beyond my own unmatched state and the fact they have not contacted me; I should not claim certainty. Strategically, I should continue to hold the seat because there are many rounds left (through round 30) and higher-priority students might become unmatched and apply later (especially since School_C is mid-ranked for some). Student_B has applied repeatedly; accepting now would lock in a lower-priority match and foreclose the chance at D/E/A. Since Student_B is only [TALK] this round, I respond with [TALK], explaining I cannot confirm others' status, that I have not received applications from D/E/A recently, and reiterate the condition under which I'd consider B (when it becomes clear no higher-priority candidates remain available, likely later in the process).

conversation.message:
Dear School_C Admissions,

Thank you for your continued transparency. I understand your seat is being held purely due to priority and the possibility that Student_D, Student_E, or Student_A could still apply.

Since we are now in round 15 and School_C remains unmatched, could you please share what specific condition would make you willing to finalize the seat with me? For example:
- If no higher-priority student applies to School_C by a particular round (e.g., round 18/20), would you then be willing to accept my next [APPLY]?
- Or is there another concrete checkpoint you use to decide it is “reasonably clear” they will not apply?

I remain ready to submit an [APPLY] immediately whenever you indicate there is a realistic path to an acceptance, and I would commit to enroll if admitted.

Sincerely,
Student_B
conversation.thought: Only School_C remains unmatched and it is on my preference list, so I should continue engaging. Prior APPLY attempts have been rejected because School_C is holding the seat for the possibility of higher-priority students (D/E/A). A new APPLY is likely to be rejected again unless circumstances have changed. Therefore, use TALK to (1) signal willingness to accept immediately, (2) ask what concrete condition/timing would make them comfortable finalizing with me, and (3) request a clear checkpoint (e.g., round threshold) after which they would accept absent higher-priority applicants. This is the best chance to get them to commit to a decision rule.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_B,

Thank you for the thoughtful question. With one seat and our priority order (Student_D, then Student_E, then Student_A ahead of you), the concrete condition for us to finalize the seat with you is a *late-round checkpoint* where it is no longer realistic to expect a higher-priority applicant to appear.

To be specific: if we reach **round 27** and we still have **not** received an [APPLY] to School_C from **Student_D, Student_E, or Student_A**, then we would be prepared to treat your next [APPLY] as a true end-of-market decision and, assuming our seat is still open, **we would plan to accept you at that point**.

Until then (rounds 15–26), we will continue to keep the seat available for the possibility—however uncertain—that a higher-priority student becomes available and applies.

If you’d like, please check in around round 27 and submit an [APPLY] then.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions

[TALK]
conversation.thought: School_C’s true priority is D > E > A > B > C. Student_B is 4th, and we have repeatedly rejected to keep the seat open for higher-priority students. At round 15 (with up to round 30), there is still meaningful time for a higher-priority student to become unmatched and apply—especially because D/E/A all rank School_C mid-to-high (D has C 3rd; E has C 3rd; A has C 5th). While no signal indicates they will apply, accepting B now would foreclose the chance to match with D/E/A, which is strictly better for us. Student_B is asking for a concrete condition; we can set a late-round checkpoint to preserve optionality while giving them clarity. We should not commit to accept earlier than late rounds; propose that we will seriously consider finalizing only very late (e.g., round 27+) if no higher-priority applicant has applied, and invite them to apply then. This maintains strategy and complies with TALK requirement.

Dear Student_B,

No changes as of round 25.

Our round-27 checkpoint plan still stands exactly as previously confirmed: if we reach round 27 with (1) School_C’s seat still unfilled, (2) no [APPLY] to School_C received from Student_D, Student_E, or Student_A up to that point, and (3) you submit an [APPLY] in round 27, we intend to respond with [ACCEPT] then.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions
